positive.review:
[h1] This game is amazing. But it's not for everyone. [/h1]
[h2]This is not a review, this is a warning.[/h2]

If you are looking for a fun game that is easy to pick up, don't play this game.
This game is meant for people who have patience and are willing to put up with esoteric controls and vague goals.

But if you put up with it and wade through all the obtuse controls and vagueness, you will find that this game is a gem not usually talked about. The story is incredible and the environments look amazing.
The ecology is incredible as well and the world feels alive.

And after some more time, the controls will feel buttery smooth and everything will be clear in hindsight. You'll be able to understand how the game works through careful observation and experimentation.

If you need help, there's wonderful people over in the Rain World discord that are willing to help and guide you through the game.

Rain World is simply one of the best games of 2017, atleast the most innovative, like what do you mean theres advanced AI, and Perpetual Animation in a single game? I mean Rain World is basically a playground for computer nerds.

The story of Rain World is one of the best parts, the slugcat is insignificant compared to what's actaully happening, I wont spoil anything, but this game has environmental story telling, so pay attention to everything if it looks detailed enough, someone also made a lore breakdown which is outdated now but its one of the most cinematic lore breakdowns of Rain World, its called The Affairs of Passing Gods.

As for the gameplay, it is very difficult at first, which is why critics hated it, alot of people spend 5 minutes in the first area and leave a bad review because they didnt THINK and PAY ATTENTION to their surroundings, they always expect games to take their hand and help them every step of the way, not Rain World, in this game youll be fully immersed in the world, you and slugcat at the start of the game are already very similar, waking up in an unfamiliar environment and seeing wierd creatures, the only tutorial the game gives is what the slugcat knows, the game will still occasionally give hints, but its only mechanics you need to know in order to progress the game.

Anyways to summarize this, Rain World has alot of advanced computer stuff, is very difficult at first, and has great story, my only problem is room CC_C08 (only rw vets will know)

Rain World is a very well made game with it's eco system, making the player seem like they're apart of it whilst not running it which is a very impressive feat to pull off and I like it that way. Although it doesn't hold your hand most of the time and does require a lot of trial and error to actually survive through the eco system with your only help being a short tutorial on very basic movement and a guide what can be killed leading you to your way. 
[b] If trial and error, non hand holding gameplay isn't your thing I wouldn't suggest picking it up though. [/b]

The story hidden within the world is also very interesting, but I wouldn't want to spoil it. But if you do want to uncover some information about this world, try bringing a coloured pearl found within The Survivor's campaign to an NPC what can be found later on within the story. Hint: Go to the Blue one after receiving something from the pink and orange one.

Despite what people tell you, I would suggest going through The Monk's campaign for a much easier first time then going for The Survivor's campaign next for the more difficult experience but The Survivor is a very good start too if you're wanting the more intended experience.
Before you decide to buy this game, just remember this game will make you mad. Especially if you're playing with friends, and you will still continue playing it.

When I first got this game, I actually refunded it. I was annoyed at a lot of things--the initial lack of direction, how everything was out to get you, and what felt like too little time to explore the world.

I purchased it again and I can tell you that this is exactly what makes the game charming. You'll absolutely get mad if you play this game--I don't know how many times I rage quit myself--but the enjoyment comes from learning the nature of the game, understanding your role as your character, and going where you want while the world moves around you. The scenery and music are also a great bonus!

It's a great game. I've only played it for around 100 hours, but I've continued to think about it for much longer. Definitely try it out!

As alien and unique as this game appears on the surface, its world is strangely familiar to the mysterious magic of our own lives.

- Awakening in an ancient world of mystery. 
- Guided by a seemingly higher intelligence through symbols & intuition.
- Exploring liminal underground spaces, to the most cosmic voids of heights.
- Slowly gaining wisdom of the numinous ecosystem woven into the ghost of a forgotten time.

All lived through a small, squishy slugcat.

It's lonely. It's alien. It's a labyrinth. It's dangerous. It's difficult...
And yet it's somehow so hopeful, inspiring, and filled with joy.

A loving, higher awareness seems to haunt your path as you quietly (or not) move through its realms. The ecosystem breaths with the ancient hum of sacred machinery as its vessel.

There's this comfort in Rain World that reflects the magic of the human experience:
The intuition, the trial & errors, the unknown, the meaning-making, the hope.

There's a pure soul-acknowledgment in this game that left me bittersweet, just like life.
Its beautiful how the most niche of games can be the most impactful... and cute.

TLDR: This is a VERY good game that ISN'T necessarily challenging mechanics or reactions-wise, but really tests your patience. Lots of things are vague in this game and you WILL be dying, doing plenty of runbacks, and backtracking a lot because of the learn-things-yourself mentality of this game. 

Anyways, here is my specific contribution to the reviews.
I played and beat the game completely blind. 
Do not do that!!! 

This game doesn't always do a great job of telling you where to go, so there will be a lot of backtracking to be had. Sure, a lot of the fun in this game is finding things out, which is definitely what the developers intended, but not all players would be quick to pick up on subtle hints, if any, that the game hands out. And as such, there will be times of frustration and annoyance. If you have been stuck exploring around a shelter/location for a few deaths or cycles with no idea where to go or just don't want to spend time slugging your way towards unexplored parts of the map again and again, don't be afraid to consult a guide. It doesn't mean you're bad at the game or are "ruining" it. This game just does that good of a job of making you feel like a scared little animal. And that isn't for everyone, especially those who (understandably) want to chuck a controller at wall due to dying over and over and over again.

Don't get me wrong, I believe this game is both artistically and technically impressive. Rain World isn't even mechanically hard in the way that games like the Soulsbornes or Elden Ring are hard, since I believe anyone of any skill level can beat this game. It's more of a question of how pissed off you get at dying again... and again... to the stupidest reasons imaginable. Or how many times you'll inevitably retrace your steps through areas you've seen before due to the rain limiting the time you have for foraging and finding paths that *might* lead you forwards, all the while dealing with particularly hungry lizards and other beasts.

But if you have a decent tolerance for struggling like I do, I can guarantee this is an experience you won't want to miss.

This game.. is probably the best game I've ever played. I'm not joking.

Playing as each individual slugcat gave me so much gameplay to play through that I was thinking about this game every moment of every day. From the very beginning when you just view it as another survival game to playing as the last downpour campaign and watching the whole overarching storyline come to a close. despite the fact that most of the slugcats live in completely different time periods, never even meeting each other, seeing characters, wildlife, and the world as a whole evolve from the scattered perspective of each individual campaign gives each and every one a sense of importance. Every character is there for a reason, and sometimes getting specific endings as some unlock new endings for others set afterwards in the timeline, even if you're supposed to play through them before it. 

Which is another thing; the order in which you play the campaigns isn't in the chronological one, meaning that in some campaigns you already know what happens afterwards, or what effect your actions have, which isn't necessarily bad, as in some cases it gives your actions more importance. In one campaign specifically you help a certain character in a dire situation [spoiler]deliver a message[/spoiler] , and what you comes afterwards makes the ending of that campaign all the more emotional (I won't elaborate more to avoid giving major spoilers). 

The OST is really good as well; when a predator comes onto the room or you anger a reputation-based creature, hearing the threat music immediately rise is an incredibly used tool for showing a creature's relationship with you in a 2D game with a pixelly animation style, where body language isn't as obvious. Also the songs are good. including the songs that sometimes just play if there's no music or if you're in a specific room, and in certain lore related songs there's a motif that plays throughout them all (it's the same one as in the main menu for reference). When playing this game enough all the songs create an atmosphere as complex as the games ecosystem. Also when he rain comes everything goes quiet even if there are predators, which is very ambient

Also every creature has certain relationships with other creatures, from wanting to eat, to considering a part of its pack, to fighting for territory with, to ignoring completely. and when you start a cycle or enter a new region, it loads every room in the region, as well as the positions and desires of every. single. creature. meaning you can enter a room and witness a fight between two creatures already in action.

As my final point the symbolism used in this game is crazy. While at the beginning of the game to karma symbols (the things in the bottom left of your screen when you open the map) seem like just random symbols they each have their own lore-related meaning. There's also another, even more lore-related symbol that is used a lot more heavily throughout the game, but even mentioning any of it would spoil a lot, and I mean a lot.

TL;DR Everything about this game is good. Just play it, and keep playing even when you die at every possible point because you get better and it gets a lot more interesting than just a survival game trust me.

So I 100% the base game of Rain-World, and I’ve yet to buy any DLC. I have a bit of a mixed review, so while I will recommend it, there are some issues that I think, if sorted out, could make it a really good game, but first the positives. The art style, the world, the music, and the playing of the game felt great, and all of the unique areas that you can go to are really awe-inspiring and just plain cool. I thought the story was really good too, though hampered by a few things that I will talk about in the negatives. I really like that sense that there’s no dialogue; it adds to that fear of being a small thing in a big world, and that really drew me in. The mods for this game were really cool! There was a nice mix of cosmetic and balancing changes that you could find, and overall the community seems pretty cool and helpful.

     Now for the negatives. I feel like many people would disagree with this, but I find the (guide, the little yellow one) quite incompetent, and I think that was because of how his AI was set up. I typically would go around in circles in the first area, and he wouldn't lead me to the right areas or the path forward. It was also hard because he kept popping in and out of different areas before he would show me what he wanted me to do. Before I looked at the wiki and did a deep dive into everything about the game, I was very frustrated by this and confused about why he wouldn’t take me in the right direction. In fact, I had to go to the wiki to figure out where to go and how the karma system works so that I could progress the game. In this way, having no dialogue for the tutorial aside from what you need to survive hampered my gameplay, and for years kept me from playing this game. Eventually, though, I found the drive to finish it, and it was great, so this is what I would suggest to fix this problem.

     While I think the Karma system is a good system that makes you have to survive for several days. I wasn't able to see all of the symbols for each Karma level, which meant that when I went to a door I wasn't sure at first if that meant it was Karma or if it was just some artistic decision. I think showing the player in the intro cutscene gaining Karma, or letting us see all of the Karma symbols when we die or sleep, would help to inform how the Gates work without saying anything. I also would like the guide to direct me in the correct direction (Sorry for being vague but I don't want to spoil where to go as that's part of the adventure). I know its AI keeps it from putting itself into danger, but that really causes me to get lost, so I think that maybe him showing you the direction to go toward the gates and then secondary resources like food would help. That way you could reach a door, realize you don't have the ‘key,’ and then progress your Karma tracker until you can open that door to progress. Aside from that, I'd like more of a reason to go to each of the zones during the main story instead of to a particular location high up and then a particular location low down. Like gaining items and bringing them somewhere, or changing the state of the world in some way, such as opening a dam to let water through into an area or something.”

     Overall, I do recommend the game. I just think that with some small tweaks, you could still keep the difficulty this game is known for without losing the player along the way. Thank you, btw, V, for helping get me into the game again. I couldn't have done it without you!

This game will forever hold a special place in my heart as one of my favorites; as a somewhat niche indie that I discovered and went through mostly blind, a proper experience of discovery, experimentation, and the marvelous cruelty of nature, it captivates me in a way very few others have. 
The atmosphere alone is a key component to my enjoyment of it; the pixel graphics have such a natural element to them with how much is interactable in subtle ways and how all the creatures move based off of their AI. It all feels natural and ties together to simulate a proper ecosystem both in visuals, audio, and gameplay.
On topic of gameplay, while it is very freeform with minimal explanation, I find that to be a beautiful aspect of the game in its own right. It lets you draw your own conclusions and forces you to experiment with the mechanics, rewarding your natural curiosity if you're not afraid of failure. It can feel unfair (especially at first) because you're a small piece of a greater ecosystem, but you can even flip that dynamic on its head with enough caution, patience, and knowledge. Once you've accustomed yourself to the controls, the game is only as difficult as you make it for yourself.  The information is there for you, the solution is there for you.
You'll need to embrace a little bit of failure, but you'll eventually be met with success and progress on the journey.
It is up to you to adapt.

When playing it for the first time, the experience is just incredible, unlike anything else.
The ecosystem simulation is really sick and the art is very good. All the animals ingame interact with each other - hunting, being preyed upon, fighting for territory and food. There's (almost) always a bigger fish.
Unless you get severely stumped, don't spoil anything for yourself, the first time experience is the best gaming experience I have ever had. If you don't know what to do, just keep exploring until you make progress. If it feels too painful and slow, looking up a map is probably fine, but don't do that too much.
Keep in mind that this game is not for the weak or lighthearted. The cute little wawa creature WILL die over and over again until you git gud (or get lucky) and progress.
If you, just like me, like small features, QoL fixes and modding in general, the game's workshop will make you happy. It's basically 100% integrated and requires little-to-no skill or modding knowledge to use. It's so peak.
(By default the camera is static and kinda bad, but SBCameraScroll from the workshop fixes the issue completely!)

The first ever slug type game.

You take the role of a stupid fucking idiot who is only able to eat sleep jump and throw things. Barely balacing on its tiny little legs having to survive the most brutal ecosystem ever, simulating how it's like to live in northern europe during winter.

Each creature has its own routine, just like Skyrim.

But contrarily to Skyrim, everything wants to eat you. As soon as you get out of your shelter you are charged by 15 different lizards, creating a beatiful rainbow of pain and suffering. Only the smartest slugcat will survive. The smartest being the one who can do a 360 backflip over the lizards impaling them to death with a tetanus shot.

Controlling the slugcat really makes you feel like you have never hold a controller in your hands. Each action plays like a game of chess, but you are only controlling pawns and the opponent has 15 queens.

The most peculiar aspect of the game is the fact that the entire ecosystem is simulated. So, each time you spawn so all the others creatures do. Leading to funny situations where you never know what you're gonna find in the next room (usually lizards, sometimes vultures, mostly both).

But venturing through this dense and intricate ecosystem is really a once in a lifetime experience. The feelings you will get from Rain World's main campaign are truly unique and special. In a market where AAA studios only chase trends and add fucking genAI to their slop, seeing real artificial intelligence on par with beasts like F.E.A.R. and Alien Isolation is really refreshing. I highly recommend the base game!

Now let's get to REAL DEAL.

The main dish, for the community, is Downpour. I disagree. Downpour is a nice addition you shouldn't take too seriously.

Its core design idea completely contrasts with the main game's concept.

Now slugcats can become AC130s, fart out spears, eat THE WORLD, and many other things that really makes them feel like they have superpowers. Which is fun, sometimes, but really should be treated as a fun bonus thingy in my opinion.

I did have some fun with Downpour, but its absolutely all over the place balacing often undermined my experience, making way more evident how sometimes if you make it to the next shelter, it's just because you had RNG luck.

from most fun to snoooore:

Arteficer
Rivulet
Saint
Spearmaster
Gourmand

The top and bottom positions are perfect examples of Downpour's issues:

In both campaigns you literally get fucked by enemies. They are really not sugarcoating it.

With the key difference being that in Arteficer's campaign, the campaign structure and level designs perfectly aids the main mechanics: the abilty to create explosives and double jumps.

The game constantly throws at you hordes of scavengers, whch, don't get me wrong, kill you many many many times. But each time you feel like it was your fault. Because you have all the tools to fight them, you just need to get good at using them.

In Spearmaster's campaign, you have the ability to infinitely generate spears and hold two at a time, but you can't eat. Instead, you have to stab enemies and suck the life out of them. The bigger the enemy the more food you get out of it.

Main problem is, the entire campaign plays like a fetch quest. So you spend most of the time carrying something around. Removing one of the slots you would use for your second spear, making encounters a drag.

In this campaign, the design actively goes against the character's mechanics, and I think that's wasted potential.

Does this make it not worth playing? That's on you and how much you like to tryhard (I really like tryharding)

I love this game. I would recommend it one hundred times over - its soundtrack, its art, its gameplay... I adore it. What I love most of all is its atmosphere. Rainworld pulls absolutely no punches, it is unfair, and it is hard - but it is winnable. The best part of the game is trying over and over to win and finally building the knowledge and skills you need to progress.

The creature design itself is delightful, the Iterators are intensely loveable despite their flawed personalities, and the critters are so memorable. I don't think theres a single creature in this game that isnt recognizable - them AND their movement.

My number one recommendation is that if you are someone who loses motivation upon losing over and over - play it with a friend! (Or don't be afraid to use some cheats if you are the type of person who doesn't mind that). Despite the games difficulty, there are options for managing struggle (I know I appreciated this as someone with a limited amount of time to play games).

Rainworld is not a platformer nor a metroidvania nor well designed nor a game.

Imagine that you play as a weak critter in a living world.
What I mean is that creatures are "living" and moving around. They do their thing, hunt and fight with each-other. Some are also stand immobile, mimicking something harmless like the pole you'd use to escape a monster chasing you.

Every single thing in that world wants you dead and will one-shot you.

Predators are faster than you and can track you over several screens so don't be seen.

One big design problem is that, since they "live" they may appear right next to your spawn point, preventing you from moving at all.
I've played a bit more than one hour and the last thirty minutes have been me waiting at the top of a pole for the room to clear.
And what usually happens is that a monster that can climb the pole finally enters the room, get me and I have to try again: waiting for the room to clear, dying, and loop again.

To make things even worse, if by miracle the path clears, the rain may fall.
Like the hanging sword of Damocles, that thing will come at the worst time and kill you.
Why? Because fuck you, that's why.

The application has one thing going for it: it's gorgeous.

And it [i]is[/i] an application. It's not a game. At best it's a simulation of being a worthless chew-toy in a horrible world. A game don't pit you randomly in a no-win state and hope you'll stay along long enough to progress.

If your idea of fun is to wait for minutes at a time for the chance to move one screen and die again and again and again without making progress, this is a perfect fit.

Rain World is gorgeous. Absolutely stunning. It plays smoothly, the unique art style really is something to gaze at, and it makes for an excellent backdrop to it's setting.

However, this game hates you. You're trying to survive in a horribly hostile world where you're prey to everything except bugs (and sometimes even then, you never know). The game is very challenging. There's little incentive to explore the game save for "find a better spot to harvest food". Occasionally you'll come across something neat, like a gate that opens if you have hibernated enough times. Problem is, you'll likely die before you can get to the next shelter inside the new area, which then sets your 'symbol'(?) down a notch, forcing you to play another cycle in the boring old area you've already explored.

This game has what might very well be the absolute worst new player experience I've ever encountered. I went in blind, and after my two hours of repeated deaths, I know basically two things. 1), purple and red enemies are more dangerous than green ones, and 2) you don't know what an enemy is. I understand the "die and try again" mentality, however these deaths are not only very punishing to deal with (setting you back a symbol notch), but they also are extremely random. You'll die to something that looks like climbable object, something that looks like grass, a green lizard hidden in the smallest, most extraordinarily hidden cranny, a bug that you thought was friendly but decides to shove you to your death, a purple lizard that (with no warning and to your complete horror) can climb the same objects you could, etc. There is literally no warning, nay, no whisper of a hint that something will kill you. You die in one hit (two if you're extremely lucky), so there isn't even any reaction you can make except "oh, that's another notch back.". 

Also, you're told nothing. The tutorial tells you that you need a certain amount of food points to sleep in a shelter, that you have limited time during a cycle, and the basic controls. That's it. Nothing else is told. There is no in game guide like Terraria, no journal like Minecraft, not even any written text on ANYTHING. You get radio silence on everything you find and you're expected to be content with being in the dark the whole game.

The unforgiving nature of the game, the complete lack of direction for the player, the utter confusion you'll feel playing this; it all lends itself to a pretty frustrating game experience. If you're looking for a game that forces you to have to figure it out at every step and punishes you for being new (and not telling you anything), Rain World will be a hit for you. If you want a relaxing game (in which this game presents itself as at first glance), you're in the wrong place. I'm certain this game is great, amazing even, in it's own niche community, I just couldn't bring myself to fight through the annoyance to find out if anything good is buried underneath.

Rainworld is not a platformer nor a metroidvania nor well designed nor a game.

Imagine that you play as a weak critter in a living world.
What I mean is that creatures are "living" and moving around. They do their thing, hunt and fight with each-other. Some are also stand immobile, mimicking something harmless like the pole you'd use to escape a monster chasing you.

Every single thing in that world wants you dead and will one-shot you.

Predators are faster than you and can track you over several screens so don't be seen.

One big design problem is that, since they "live" they may appear right next to your spawn point, preventing you from moving at all.
I've played a bit more than one hour and the last thirty minutes have been me waiting at the top of a pole for the room to clear.
And what usually happens is that a monster that can climb the pole finally enters the room, get me and I have to try again: waiting for the room to clear, dying, and loop again.

To make things even worse, if by miracle the path clears, the rain may fall.
Like the hanging sword of Damocles, that thing will come at the worst time and kill you.
Why? Because fuck you, that's why.

The application has one thing going for it: it's gorgeous.

And it [i]is[/i] an application. It's not a game. At best it's a simulation of being a worthless chew-toy in a horrible world. A game don't pit you randomly in a no-win state and hope you'll stay along long enough to progress.

If your idea of fun is to wait for minutes at a time for the chance to move one screen and die again and again and again without making progress, this is a perfect fit.

Rain World is gorgeous. Absolutely stunning. It plays smoothly, the unique art style really is something to gaze at, and it makes for an excellent backdrop to it's setting.

However, this game hates you. You're trying to survive in a horribly hostile world where you're prey to everything except bugs (and sometimes even then, you never know). The game is very challenging. There's little incentive to explore the game save for "find a better spot to harvest food". Occasionally you'll come across something neat, like a gate that opens if you have hibernated enough times. Problem is, you'll likely die before you can get to the next shelter inside the new area, which then sets your 'symbol'(?) down a notch, forcing you to play another cycle in the boring old area you've already explored.

This game has what might very well be the absolute worst new player experience I've ever encountered. I went in blind, and after my two hours of repeated deaths, I know basically two things. 1), purple and red enemies are more dangerous than green ones, and 2) you don't know what an enemy is. I understand the "die and try again" mentality, however these deaths are not only very punishing to deal with (setting you back a symbol notch), but they also are extremely random. You'll die to something that looks like climbable object, something that looks like grass, a green lizard hidden in the smallest, most extraordinarily hidden cranny, a bug that you thought was friendly but decides to shove you to your death, a purple lizard that (with no warning and to your complete horror) can climb the same objects you could, etc. There is literally no warning, nay, no whisper of a hint that something will kill you. You die in one hit (two if you're extremely lucky), so there isn't even any reaction you can make except "oh, that's another notch back.". 

Also, you're told nothing. The tutorial tells you that you need a certain amount of food points to sleep in a shelter, that you have limited time during a cycle, and the basic controls. That's it. Nothing else is told. There is no in game guide like Terraria, no journal like Minecraft, not even any written text on ANYTHING. You get radio silence on everything you find and you're expected to be content with being in the dark the whole game.

The unforgiving nature of the game, the complete lack of direction for the player, the utter confusion you'll feel playing this; it all lends itself to a pretty frustrating game experience. If you're looking for a game that forces you to have to figure it out at every step and punishes you for being new (and not telling you anything), Rain World will be a hit for you. If you want a relaxing game (in which this game presents itself as at first glance), you're in the wrong place. I'm certain this game is great, amazing even, in it's own niche community, I just couldn't bring myself to fight through the annoyance to find out if anything good is buried underneath.
